title: 112_hr3012
content: The Act titled "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" imposes a numerical limitation on visas from any single foreign state. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to make changes to visa allocation and numerical limitations for high-skilled immigrants. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust visa allocation for countries exceeding the numerical limitation for immigrant visas in a fiscal year. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust visa allocation for countries exceeding the numerical limitation for immigrant visas in a fiscal year. Section 2 of the Chinese Student Protection Act of 1992 is amended to change subsections and effective dates for fiscal years starting in 2012. For fiscal years 2012 and 2013, a percentage of immigrant visas under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act will be allotted to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest numbers of immigrant visas in previous years. For fiscal year 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act will be allotted to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest numbers of immigrant visas in previous years. Per-country levels dictate that the number of visas for any single foreign state or dependent area may not exceed 25. The per-country limit for immigrant visas in a fiscal year is 25 percent for a single foreign state and 2 percent for a dependent area. Unreserved visas for fiscal years 2012-2014 should not exceed 85 percent for any single foreign state. Special rules prevent unused visas from being carried over to the next fiscal year. The per-country limit for immigrant visas is set at 25 percent for a single foreign state and 2 percent for a dependent area. Special rules apply to prevent unused visas from being carried over to the next fiscal year. Section 202(b) of the Act determines the foreign state to which an alien is chargeable for visa purposes. The House of Representatives passed the bill on November 29, 2011. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
